Pregnancy Risk Categories for Pharmacological Agents

answer.text: C = animal studies do not indicate fetal risk
D = the possibility of risk to the fetus is remote
A = controlled human studies indicate no apparent risk to the fetus
B = animal studies show an adverse effect on the fetus but there are no controlled studies in humans
X = evidence of human risk, but in certain circumtances the use of such drug may be acceptable despite its potential risk

questiontext.text: Management of oro antral communication

answer.text: If defect size is 2 mm, do the palatal flap
If the size is more than 2 mm, packing the site with collagen plug
If the sinus opening is more than 6 mm, consider surgical procedure
If a sizeable bone comes out with the tooth, put a figure of eight suture

answer.text: Warm compress and gargle with warm water

questiontext.text: A 70 years old male patient was presented in Dental hospital with intention to extract his tooth due to retained root. There was a retained root of 16 seen intra-orally. There was no contraindication for the extraction. What shape of the extarction forcep used in this matter

answer.text: L shaped, sharp buccal beak (buccal furcation) and sharp palatal beak (palatal furcation)
S shaped, both beaks are rounded and open
I shaped, both beaks are rounded and open
S shaped, sharp buccal beak (buccal furcation) and a rounded and open palatal beak
S shaped, a rounded buccal beak and sharp palatal beak (palatal furcation with open beak)

questiontext.text: A dentist will perform an extraction procedure on a deciduous tooth with a grade 3 mobility. Firstly, the doctor anesthetizes the patient with a topical anesthetic spray. Additional equipment needed for anesthetic administration in this case is?

A dentist will perform an extraction procedure on a deciduous tooth with a grade 3 mobility. The dentist decided to anesthetize the patient with a topical anesthetic in a gel form. Additional equipment needed for anesthetic administration in this case is?
One of the armamentarium that is mostly used for tooth extraction, especially for adult patients, is the dental elevator. The main functions of dental elevator are listed below, excluding…

answer.text: To split teeth which have grooves cut in them
To remove roots, fractured or carious teeth
To loosen teeth prior to application of forceps

questiontext.text: Forceps are designed to provide adequate access to the targeted tooth without injuring the neighboring tissues. When doing tooth extraction in the upper and lower jaws, a dentist will use different kinds of forceps. The basic characteristic that can be seen to differentiate the maxillary and mandibular forceps are?

answer.text: The beaks of maxillary forceps are at a right angle to the handle, whereas the beaks of mandibular forceps are parallel.
The beaks of both maxillary and mandibular forceps are parallel to the handle.
The beaks of maxillary forceps are parallel to the handle, whereas the beaks of mandibular forceps are at a right angle.
The beaks of both maxillary and mandibular forceps are at a right angle to the handle.
The beaks of maxillary forceps are shorter than that of mandibular forceps.

questiontext.text: A dentist will do an extraction procedure to the maxillary central incisor tooth using maxillary anterior forceps. The main characteristics to recognize this forceps are?

answer.text: Beaks are approximated with each other and handle is straight.
Handle has concavity on one side to provide better grip and access.
Handle is similar to that of premolar forceps.
Beaks are curved and angulated.
Beak is pointed on one side which engages the buccal bifurcation of roots

answer.text: Upper - Deciduous Anterior Teeth Forceps
Upper - Deciduous Molar Forceps
Lower - Deciduous Anterior Teeth Forceps
Upper - Deciduous Canine Forceps

answer.text: Causes tissue injury or tissue reaction

questiontext.text: The most commonly used thread size for intraoral use is mentioned as...

answer.text: 6–0 or 00000 sizes

questiontext.text: In the oral cavity, usually, the dentist will use a non-resorbable suture material to close the wound. The most commonly used non-resorbable suture in dentistry is…

After doing tooth extraction with an open method, it is very important to choose the appropriate type of needle to facilitate the suturing process. In the choices below, which type of needle is most suitable for use in the intraoral soft tissue?
Similar to a hemostat, the needle holder is used to grasp and manipulate the suture needle to which the thread is attached. What is the main feature to differentiates this tool?

answer.text: The faces of the beaks of the needle holder are cross-hatched, while the faces of the hemostat have parallel grooves.
A hemostat has a thicker beak compared with the needle holder.
The faces of the beaks of the needle holder are parallel grooves, while the faces of the hemostat have cross-hatched.
The faces of the beaks of the needle holder are parallel-hatched, while the faces of the hemostat have parallel grooves.
A hemostat has a shorter beak compared with the needle holder.

questiontext.text: As compared with somatic pain, all of the following are true about visceral pain, EXCEPT

answer.text: it is dull and vague
it is often associated with nausea and vomiting
it is poorly localized
it may follow the distribution of asomatic nerve
it is often periodic and builds to peaks

questiontext.text: The following statements are true regarding preemptive analgesia, EXCEPT

answer.text: local anesthetics, opioids, and COX inhibitors can be used for preemptive analgesia
early postoperative pain is not a significant predictor of long-term pain
preemptive analgesia is helpful in reducing postoperative pain in part by reducing the phenomenon of central sensitization

preemptive analgesia is thought to reduce neuroplastic changes in the spinal

cord
preemptive analgesia may have the potential to prevent the development of chronic pain states

questiontext.text: An advantage of selective COX-2 inhibitors over nonselective COX inhibitors is

answer.text: inhibit production of thromboxane A2
fewer GI side effects

questiontext.text: Which one of the following medications is MOST selective for inhibiting COX-2?

answer.text: Ibuprofen

questiontext.text: A 78-kg, 36-year-old patient is undergoing odontectomy impacted molar 3. After uneventful induction of general anesthesia with placement of Endotracheal tube, cefazolin 2 gm IV is being administered, when there is a sudden increase in airway pressure, wheezing, tachycardia, and decreased blood pressure. In addition to stopping infusion of cefazolin, an IV fluid bolus, and administration of 100% oxygen, which one of the following actions is most appropriate?

answer.text: administration of IV epinephrine and IV glucocorticoid
administration of IV dopamine and IV glucocorticoid
administration of subcutaneous epinephrine and IV glucocorticoid
administration of IV glucocorticoid and phenylephrine
administration of diphenhydramine and ephedrine

questiontext.text: An anaesthetist administers 0.5% bupivacaine as part of an Local anesthetic for extraction impacted molar 3.One minute after completing the injection, the patient complains of dizziness, difficulty in breathing and then starts to convulse. She then suffers a VF cardiac arrest. The most appropriate management in the first 4 minutes would be:

answer.text: Defibrillation, CPR, adrenaline, amiodarone.
Defibrillation, CPR, adrenaline, Caesarean section.
CPR, defibrillation, 20% Intralipid, Caesarean section.
CPR, defibrillation, adrenaline, 20% Intralipid.
CPR, adrenaline, 20% Intralipid, Caesarean section.

questiontext.text: A 18-year-old female presents to the accident and emergency department having taken about 50 tablets of paracetamol. She says that she swallowed the tablets within the last 20 minutes. Which of the following treatments would be the most effective in reducing absorption of paracetamol?

answer.text: N-acetyl cysteine.

questiontext.text: A 9-year-old boy weighing 40kg is undergoing an cleft palate repair.He became severely hypotensive 5 minutes after the administration of an antibiotic. He developed a rash all over his body. His blood pressure is 65/45mmHg, his heart rate is 140 per minute and he has weak central pulses. The most appropriate dose and route of administering adrenaline is:

answer.text: 0.1ml/kg of 1: 20 000 adrenaline IM.
0.1ml/kg of 1:1000 adrenaline IV.
0.1ml/kg of 1:100 000 adrenaline IV.
0.1ml/kg of 1:10 000 adrenaline IM.
0.1ml/kg of 1:10 000 adrenaline IV.

questiontext.text: A 70-year-old man is scheduled for extraction molar under local anesthesia. Soon after injection of 20ml of 0.5% bupivacaine, he became unresponsive. He is unconscious and has no palpable carotid pulse. CPR is commenced. Which one of the following best describes the specific treatment in this scenario?

answer.text: 1ml/kg of 10% lipid emulsion over 1 minute.
1.5ml/kg of 20% lipid emulsion over 1 minute.
1.5ml/kg of 20% lipid emulsion over 5 minutes.
1ml/kg of 10% lipid emulsion over 1 minute.
1.5ml/kg of 10% lipid emulsion over 2 minutes.

questiontext.text: Benefits of epinephrine 1:200,000 added to lidocaine for an local anesthesia procedure include all of the following, except

answer.text: Prevent complication of Injection Local Anesthetic Agent
Prophylactic treatment of hypotension associated with the bolus administration of lidocaine
Prolongation of duration of action of lidocaine
Delayed absorption into systemic circulation, thereby decreasing probability of local anesthetic toxicity
Better quality of block

questiontext.text: Failure of an oroantral fistula to heal is generally due to

answer.text: lack of nerve supply to flap
Infection or because a drain or gauze and inserted after floor of antrum are perforated

questiontext.text: When the flap used to done on oroantral fistula breaks down it is due to..

answer.text: lack blood supply because of improper design to infection or excessive suture design
lack of nerve supply to flap

questiontext.text: The treatment for a tooth or root displaced into the sinus is

answer.text: enucleation with space obliteration and primary closure
Removal by means of a caldwell luc operation

questiontext.text: Treatment of oroantral fistula consist of

answer.text: Enucleation with space obliteration and primary closure
Plastic closure of fistula combined with caldwell luc operation to clean up infection on the antrum

questiontext.text: The caldwell luc operation is used for

answer.text: Treatment of osteoma of mandibular condyle
Removal tooth and fragment or roots in the antrum

questiontext.text: Treatment of facial paralysis is

answer.text: Cortizone (50mg) three time daily for five day

questiontext.text: Prevention of toxicity involves the following
Syncope

answer.text: Always associated with loss of conciousness
Symptoms of allergic reactions of local anesthesia
Perhaps the intra treatment complication associated with local anesthesia
The local treatment complication of local anesthesia

questiontext.text: Treatment of odontogenic maxillary sinusitis consist of

answer.text: Enucleation and primary closure plus space obliteration
Dressing sinus membrane with ethyl chloride
Drainage and irrigation on the caldwell luc operation
